26.text: So when his servants told David these things, David was pleased to become the king's son-in-law. And when the time had not yet expired,

27.text: David rose up and went, he and his men; and he struck down two hundred Philistine men. And David brought their foreskins, and they gave them in full number to the king, that he might become the king's son-in-law. And Saul gave him Michal his daughter as wife.

28.text: And Saul saw and knew that Jehovah was with David. And Michal the daughter of Saul loved him.

29.text: And Saul was even more afraid of David, and Saul was David's enemy from then on.

30.text: Then the princes of the Philistines went forth; and as often as they went forth, David succeeded more than all the servants of Saul. So his name was very highly esteemed.

1.text: And Saul told Jonathan his son and all his servants to kill David. But Jonathan, Saul's son, took great delight in David.

2.text: And Jonathan told David, saying, Saul my father is seeking to kill you. Now therefore be on guard in the morning, and stay in some secret place, and hide yourself.

3.text: And I will go out and stand by my father's side in the field where you are. And I will speak about you to my father; and if I learn anything, I will tell you.

4.text: So Jonathan spoke well about David to Saul his father and said to him, May the king not sin against his servant David, because he has not sinned against you, and because his deeds have been very good for you.

5.text: For he risked his life when he struck down the Philistine, and Jehovah accomplished a great salvation for all Israel. You saw it and rejoiced. Why then will you sin against innocent blood by having David killed without cause?

6.text: And Saul listened to the voice of Jonathan; and Saul swore, As Jehovah lives, he shall not be put to death.

7.text: Then Jonathan called David, and Jonathan told him all these things. And Jonathan brought David to Saul, and he was in his presence as before.

8.text: And there was war again. And David went out and fought against the Philistines. And he struck them with a great slaughter, and they fled from before him.

9.text: Then there came an evil spirit from Jehovah upon Saul, and he sat in his house with his spear in his hand while David played the lyre by hand.

10.text: And Saul sought to strike David even to the wall with the spear, but he slipped away from Saul's presence. And Saul struck the wall with his spear, but David fled and escaped that night.

11.text: Then Saul sent messengers to David's house to watch him and kill him in the morning. And Michal, David's wife, told him, saying, If you do not save your life tonight, in the morning you will be killed.

12.text: So Michal let David down through the window, and he went away and fled and escaped.

13.text: Then Michal took the teraphim and laid it in the bed. And she put a net of goats' hair on its head and covered it with clothing.

14.text: And when Saul sent messengers to take David, she said, He is sick.

15.text: And Saul sent the messengers to see David, saying, Bring him up to me on his bed that I may kill him.

16.text: And when the messengers went in, there was the teraphim in the bed with a net of goats' hair on its head.

17.text: Then Saul said to Michal, Why have you deceived me like this and let my enemy go so that he has slipped away? And Michal said to Saul, He said to me, Let me go; why should I kill you?

18.text: So David fled and slipped away and came to Samuel at Ramah, and he told him all that Saul had done to him. And he and Samuel went and dwelt at Naioth.

19.text: Then it was told Saul, saying, David is now at Naioth in Ramah.

20.text: So Saul sent messengers to seize David; and when they saw the company of prophets prophesying and Samuel standing and presiding over them, the Spirit of God came upon Saul's messengers, and they also prophesied.

21.text: And it was told Saul, and he sent other messengers, and they also prophesied. And Saul again sent messengers the third time, and they also prophesied.

22.text: Then he himself went to Ramah. And he came to the great well that is in Secu; and he asked and said, Where are Samuel and David? And someone said, They are now at Naioth in Ramah.

23.text: So he went there, toward Naioth in Ramah. And the Spirit of God came upon him as well, and he went on and prophesied until he came to Naioth in Ramah.

24.text: And he also stripped off his clothes and also prophesied before Samuel, and he lay naked all that day and all that night. Therefore they say, Is Saul also among the prophets?

1.text: Then David fled from Naioth in Ramah and came and said to Jonathan, What have I done? What is my iniquity, or what is my sin before your father, that he is seeking my life?

2.text: And he said to him, Far from it! You shall not die. My father does nothing great or small that he does not disclose to me. So why should my father hide this matter from me? Such would not happen.

3.text: Then David swore again and said, Your father fully knows that I have found favor in your sight; so he says, Do not let Jonathan know about this; otherwise, he will be grieved. But truly as Jehovah lives and as your soul lives, there is but a step between me and death.

4.text: And Jonathan said to David, Whatever you say, I will do for you.

5.text: And David said to Jonathan, It is the new moon tomorrow, and I am to sit with the king at the meal. But let me go, and I will hide myself in the field until the following evening.

6.text: If your father misses me at all, you shall say, David earnestly asked leave of me to run to Bethlehem his city, for it is the yearly sacrifice there for all his family.

7.text: If he says in this way, Fine; then your servant will have peace. But if he becomes angry at all, know that evil has been determined by him.

8.text: Deal kindly then with your servant, for you have brought your servant into a covenant of Jehovah with you. But if there is any iniquity in me, you kill me. Why then should you bring me to your father?

9.text: And Jonathan said, Far be it from you! For if I knew at all that evil has been determined by my father to come upon you, would I not tell it to you?

10.text: Then David said to Jonathan, Who will tell me whether or not your father has responded to you harshly?

11.text: And Jonathan said to David, Come and let us go out into the field. And they both went out into the field.

12.text: And Jonathan said to David, By Jehovah, the God of Israel: When I search out my father about this time tomorrow, or on the following day, and if he is good toward David, I will surely send word to you and disclose it to you.

13.text: May Jehovah do so to Jonathan, and even more, if it pleases my father to do you evil, and I do not disclose it to you and send you away to go in peace. And may Jehovah be with you as He was with my father.

14.text: And while I am still alive, do show me the lovingkindness of Jehovah, that I may not die;

15.text: And never cut off your lovingkindness from my house, not even when Jehovah has cut off David's enemies to the man from the face of the earth.

16.text: So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying, And Jehovah will require it at the hand of David's enemies.

17.text: And Jonathan made David swear again by his love for him, for he loved him as he loved his own soul.

18.text: Then Jonathan said to him, Tomorrow is the new moon; and you will be missed, for your seat will be empty.

19.text: And when you have waited three days, you shall go far down and come to the place where you hid yourself while all this was happening; and you shall remain at the stone Ezel.

20.text: And I will shoot three arrows to its side, as though I were shooting at a mark.

21.text: And just then I will send a boy, saying, Go; find the arrows. If I say to the boy, The arrows are there to this side of you; gather them; then come, for you have peace and there is no problem, as Jehovah lives.

22.text: But if I speak in this way to the young man, The arrows are there beyond you; then go, for Jehovah has sent you away.

23.text: And concerning this matter that I and you have spoken of, it is Jehovah who is between me and you forever.

24.text: So David hid himself in the field. And when the new moon came, the king sat at the meal to eat.

25.text: And the king sat on his seat as at other times, on his seat near the wall; and Jonathan rose up, and Abner sat down beside Saul, but David's place was empty.

26.text: But Saul said nothing that day about it, for he thought, Something has happened to him; he is not clean; surely he is not clean.

27.text: And on the day after the new moon, the second day, David's place was empty. And Saul said to Jonathan his son, Why has the son of Jesse come neither yesterday nor today to the meal?

28.text: And Jonathan answered Saul, David asked leave of me earnestly to go to Bethlehem.

29.text: And he said, Let me go, I beg you; for our family has a sacrifice in that city, and my brother commanded me to be there. So now if I have found favor in your sight, let me slip away to see my brothers. Therefore he has not come to the king's table.

30.text: And Saul's anger burned against Jonathan, and he said to him, You son of a perverse, rebellious woman! Do I not know that you have chosen the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame of your mother's nakedness?

31.text: For as long as the son of Jesse is alive on the earth, you and your kingdom will not be established. Now therefore send someone and bring him to me, for he is as good as dead.

32.text: And Jonathan answered Saul his father and said to him, Why must he be put to death? What has he done?

33.text: But Saul threw his spear at him in order to strike him down. So Jonathan knew that it was determined by his father to put David to death.

34.text: And Jonathan rose up from the table in burning anger and did not eat any food on the second day of the new moon, for he was grieved about David because his father had shamed him.

35.text: Then in the morning Jonathan went forth to the field for the appointment with David, and a small boy was with him.

36.text: And he said to his boy, Run and find the arrows that I am shooting. While the boy was running, he shot the arrow beyond him.

37.text: And when the boy came to the place of the arrow that Jonathan had shot, Jonathan called out after the boy and said, The arrow is there beyond you.

38.text: And Jonathan called out to the boy, Hurry up quickly; do not stay there. And Jonathan's boy gathered the arrows and came to his master.

39.text: And the boy knew nothing; only Jonathan and David knew the matter.

40.text: Then Jonathan gave his equipment to his boy and said to him, Go; bring them to the city.

41.text: And when the boy went, David rose up from his hiding place toward the south and fell on his face to the ground; and he bowed himself three times. And they kissed each other; and they wept for each other, but David more greatly.

42.text: And Jonathan said to David, Go in peace, because both of us have sworn in the name of Jehovah, saying, May Jehovah be between me and you and between my seed and your seed forever. Then David rose up and left, and Jonathan went into the city.

1.text: And David went to Nob to Ahimelech the priest. And Ahimelech came trembling to meet David and said to him, Why are you alone, and no one with you?

2.text: And David said to Ahimelech the priest, The king has charged me with some matter, and he said to me, Let no man know anything about the matter that I have sent you on and charged you with. So I have made an appointment with my young men at such and such a place.

3.text: Now then what do you have on hand? Give five loaves of bread into my hand, or whatever there is to be found.

4.text: And the priest answered David and said, There is no common bread on hand; yet there is holy bread, but only if the young men have kept themselves from women.

5.text: And David answered the priest and said to him, Women have indeed been kept from us, as previously when I went forth; and the vessels of the young men were holy, even if it was a common journey. How much more then today will their vessels be holy!

6.text: So the priest gave him what was holy, for there was no bread there except the bread of the Presence, which was taken from before Jehovah, to be replaced by hot bread at the time it was taken.

7.text: Now one of Saul's servants was there that day, detained before Jehovah. His name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of the shepherds that belonged to Saul.

8.text: And David said to Ahimelech, And is there not a spear or a sword here on hand? For I have brought neither my sword nor my equipment with me, for the king's matter was urgent.

9.text: And the priest said, The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you struck down in the valley of Elah, is here, wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you will take it, take it; for there is no other here but that one. And David said, There is none like it; give it to me.

10.text: Then David rose up and fled that day from before Saul, and he went to Achish the king of Gath.

11.text: But the servants of Achish said to him, Is this not David the king of the land? Is this not him of whom they sang to one another in dances, saying, Saul has struck down his thousands; / But David, his ten thousands?

12.text: And David took these words to heart and feared Achish the king of Gath greatly.

13.text: So he disguised his sanity in their sight and acted like a madman before them, and he made marks on the doors of the gate and let his spittle run down his beard.

14.text: And Achish said to his servants, Look, you see that the man is mad. Why have you brought him to me?

15.text: Do I lack madmen that you have brought this one to me to be a madman before me? Shall this one come into my house?

1.text: Then David went from there and escaped to the cave of Adullam. And when his brothers and all his father's house heard of it, they went down to him there.

2.text: And everyone who was in distress and everyone who was in debt and everyone who was discontented gathered to him, and he became captain over them. And with him were about four hundred men.

3.text: And David went from there to Mizpeh of Moab. And he said to the king of Moab, Let my father and mother go forth and be with you until I know what God will do for me.

4.text: And he brought them before the king of Moab, and they remained with him all the time that David was in the stronghold.

5.text: And Gad the prophet said to David, Do not stay in the stronghold; depart and go into the land of Judah. So David departed and went into the forest of Hereth.

6.text: Then Saul heard that David and the men with him had been discovered. Now Saul was sitting in Gibeah, under the tamarisk tree on the height; and his spear was in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.

7.text: And Saul said to his servants standing around him, Hear now, you Benjaminites: Will the son of Jesse give every one of you fields and vineyards, will he make every one of you captains of thousands and captains of hundreds,

8.text: That every one of you has conspired against me, so that no one discloses it to me when my son makes a covenant with the son of Jesse, and none of you is sorry for me or discloses it to me when my son stirs up my servant against me to ambush me as on this day?

9.text: Then Doeg the Edomite, who was set over Saul's servants, answered and said, I saw the son of Jesse coming to Ahimelech the son of Ahitub at Nob.

10.text: And he inquired of Jehovah for him and gave him provisions, and he gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.

11.text: Then the king sent men to call Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and all his father's house, the priests who were in Nob. And all of them came to the king.

12.text: And Saul said, Hear now, you son of Ahitub. And he said, Here I am, my lord.

13.text: And Saul said to him, Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, in that you have given him food and a sword, and have inquired of God for him, so that he rises up against me to ambush me as on this day?

14.text: And Ahimelech answered the king and said, And who among all your servants is as faithful as David, who is the king's son-in-law and has access to your council and is honored in your house?

15.text: Was it just today that I began to inquire of God for him? Far be it from me! May the king not impute anything to his servant nor to all my father's house, for your servant knows nothing of this matter, small or great.

16.text: But the king said, You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all your father's house.

17.text: Then the king said to the runners who were standing around him, Turn, and kill the priests of Jehovah, because their hand is also with David, and because they knew that he was fleeing and they did not disclose it to me. But the king's servants would not put forth their hand to attack the priests of Jehovah.

18.text: And the king said to Doeg, You turn, and attack the priests. And Doeg the Edomite turned, and he attacked the priests. And on that day he killed eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod.

19.text: And he struck Nob, the city of the priests, with the edge of the sword, both men and women, infants and sucklings, and oxen and asses and sheep, with the edge of the sword.

20.text: But one of the sons of Ahimelech the son of Ahitub escaped, whose name was Abiathar, and he fled after David.

21.text: And Abiathar told David that Saul had slain the priests of Jehovah.

22.text: And David said to Abiathar, I knew on that day when Doeg the Edomite was there that he would surely tell Saul. I am responsible for all the lives of your father's house.

23.text: Remain with me, and do not be afraid; for he who seeks my life seeks your life, for you will be kept safe with me.

1.text: And some told David, saying, The Philistines are now fighting against Keilah and robbing the threshing floors.

2.text: And David inquired of Jehovah, saying, Shall I go and strike these Philistines? And Jehovah said to David, Go and strike the Philistines, and save Keilah.

3.text: And David's men said to him, Here we are, afraid here in Judah; how much more if we go to Keilah against the ranks of the Philistines!

4.text: So David inquired yet again of Jehovah. And Jehovah answered him and said, Rise up; go down to Keilah, for I am delivering the Philistines into your hand.

5.text: Then David and his men went to Keilah and fought against the Philistines and carried off their cattle and struck them down with a great slaughter. And David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.

6.text: Now it so happened that when Abiathar the son of Ahimelech fled to David at Keilah, he came down with an ephod in his hand.

7.text: Then it was told Saul that David had come to Keilah. And Saul said, God has delivered him into my hand; for he is shut in, because he has entered a city with gates and bars.

8.text: And Saul summoned all the people to battle, to go down to Keilah, to besiege David and his men.

9.text: But when David learned that Saul was planning evil against him, he said to Abiathar the priest, Bring the ephod here.

10.text: And David said, O Jehovah the God of Israel, Your servant has heard for certain that Saul is seeking to come to Keilah in order to destroy the city on my account.

11.text: Will the men of Keilah deliver me into his hand? Will Saul come down, as Your servant has heard? O Jehovah the God of Israel, do tell Your servant. And Jehovah said, He will come down.

12.text: And David said, Will the men of Keilah deliver me and my men into the hand of Saul? And Jehovah said, They will deliver you.

13.text: So David and his men, about six hundred men, rose up and went forth from Keilah; and they went about wherever they could. And when it was told Saul that David had slipped away from Keilah, he ceased his going forth.

14.text: And David remained in the wilderness in strongholds, and he remained in the hill country in the wilderness of Ziph. And Saul sought him every day, but God did not deliver him into his hand.

15.text: And David saw that Saul went forth to seek his life, and David was in the wilderness of Ziph at Horesh.

16.text: Then Jonathan the son of Saul rose up and went to David at Horesh, and he strengthened his hand in God.

17.text: And he said to him, Do not be afraid, for the hand of Saul my father will not find you; and you will become king over Israel, and I will be second to you; and even Saul my father knows that.

18.text: And the two of them made a covenant before Jehovah. And David remained in Horesh, and Jonathan went to his house.

19.text: Then some Ziphites went up to Saul at Gibeah, saying, David is indeed hiding among us in the strongholds at Horesh, on the hill of Hachilah, which is south of the desert!

20.text: Now then, O king, come down, according to all your soul's desire to come down; and we will deliver him into the hand of the king.

21.text: And Saul said, Blessed are you of Jehovah, for you have had compassion on me.

22.text: Go now, and make sure once more; and find out and look into his place, where he sets foot, who has seen him there; for I am told that he is very cunning.

23.text: And look about and learn of all his hiding places where he lurks, and come back to me with sure information; then I will go with you, and if he is in the land, I will search him out among all the thousands of Judah.

24.text: And they rose up and went to Ziph before Saul. And David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the Arabah to the south of the desert.

25.text: And Saul and his men went to seek him. And when some told David this, he went down to the rock and remained in the wilderness of Maon. And when Saul heard of it, he pursued after David in the wilderness of Maon.

26.text: And Saul went on one side of the mountain, while David and his men went on the other side of the mountain. And David hurried to get away from Saul, while Saul and his men were closing in on David and his men in order to capture them.

27.text: Then a messenger came to Saul, saying, Hurry and come, for the Philistines have raided the land.

28.text: So Saul returned from pursuing after David, and he went to meet the Philistines; therefore they call that place the Rock of Escape.

29.text: And David went up from there and remained in the strongholds of En-gedi.

1.text: And when Saul returned from following the Philistines, some told him, saying, David is now in the wilderness of En-gedi.

2.text: And Saul took three thousand choice men from all Israel and went to seek David and his men upon the Rocks of the Wild Goats.

3.text: And he came to the sheepfolds along the way, and a cave was there. And Saul went in to relieve himself. Now David and his men were sitting in the innermost part of the cave.

4.text: And David's men said to him, The day is here of which Jehovah said to you, I am about to give your enemy into your hand. Do then to him according to what seems good in your sight. So David rose up and cut off a corner of Saul's cloak without being noticed.

5.text: But afterward David's heart smote him because he had cut off a corner of Saul's cloak.

6.text: And he said to his men, Jehovah forbid that I should do such a thing to my lord, Jehovah's anointed, as stretch out my hand against him; for he is Jehovah's anointed.

7.text: So David checked his men with these words and would not allow them to rise up against Saul. And Saul rose up out of the cave and went on his way.

8.text: Then David rose up afterward and came out of the cave. And he called after Saul, saying, My lord the king. And when Saul looked behind him, David bowed with his face to the ground and paid him homage.

9.text: And David said to Saul, Why do you listen to men's words that say, David now seeks your harm?

10.text: Just this day your eyes have seen that Jehovah gave you into my hand today in the cave. And though some told me to kill you, I spared you and said, I will not stretch out my hand against my lord, for he is Jehovah's anointed.

11.text: Now my father, look, indeed, look at the corner of your cloak in my hand; for in that I cut off the corner of your cloak and did not kill you, know and see that there is no harm or transgression in my hand. And though I have not sinned against you, you hunt after my life in order to take it.

12.text: May Jehovah judge between me and you, and may Jehovah avenge me of you; but my hand will not be against you.

13.text: As the proverb of the ancients says, Out of the wicked comes forth wickedness; but my hand will not be against you.

14.text: After whom does the king of Israel come out? Whom do you pursue? A dead dog; a single flea.

15.text: May Jehovah then be Judge and decide between me and you. And may He see and plead my cause and release me through His judgment out of your hand.

16.text: And when David finished speaking these words to Saul, Saul said, Is this your voice, my son David? And Saul lifted up his voice and wept.

17.text: And he said to David, You are more righteous than I; for you have repaid me with good, while I have repaid you with evil.

18.text: And you have declared today how you did good to me, because Jehovah delivered me up into your hand, but you would not kill me.

19.text: For if a man finds his enemy, will he send him away safely? May Jehovah therefore reward you with good for what you have done to me this day.

20.text: And now I indeed know that you will surely be king and that the kingdom of Israel will be established in your hand.

21.text: Now therefore swear to me by Jehovah that you will not cut off my seed after me and that you will not destroy my name from my father's house.

22.text: So David swore to Saul. And Saul went to his house, and David and his men went up to the stronghold.

1.text: Then Samuel died, and all Israel gathered together and mourned for him; and they buried him at his house in Ramah. And David rose up and went down into the wilderness of Paran.

2.text: Now there was a man in Maon, whose possessions were in Carmel. And the man was very wealthy: He had three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. And at that time he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.

3.text: And the man's name was Nabal, and his wife's name was Abigail. And the woman had good discernment and was beautiful in appearance. But the man was hard, and he was evil in his doings; and he was a Calebite.

4.text: And David heard in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.

5.text: So David sent ten young men; and David said to the young men, Go up to Carmel, and go to Nabal and greet him in my name.

6.text: And thus shall you say, Live long; and peace be to you, and peace be to your house, and peace be to all that you have.

7.text: Now therefore I hear that you have shearers; your shepherds have now been with us, and we have not harmed them, nor has there been anything missing from them, all the time they were in Carmel.

8.text: Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore let these young men find favor in your sight, for we come in a good time. Give whatever you may have on hand to your servants and to your son David.

9.text: So David's young men went and spoke to Nabal according to all these words in the name of David; then they waited.

10.text: But Nabal answered David's servants and said, Who is David, or who is the son of Jesse? There are many servants today who break away from their masters.

11.text: Shall I then take my food and my water and my meat that I have slaughtered for my shearers, and give it to men who come from I do not know where?

12.text: Then David's young men turned back on their way. And they returned and came and told him all these things.

13.text: And David said to his men, Each man gird on his sword. And each man girded on his sword, and David also girded on his sword. And they went up after David, about four hundred men. And two hundred remained with the baggage.

14.text: But one of the young men told Abigail, Nabal's wife, saying, David has just sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master, but he shouted insultingly at them.

15.text: But the men were very good to us; and we were not harmed, nor did we miss anything all the time we went with them when we were in the fields.

16.text: They were a wall to us both by night and by day all the time we were with them tending the sheep.

17.text: Now therefore know and consider what you will do, because evil has been determined against our master and against all his house; for he is so worthless a man that no one can speak to him.

18.text: Then Abigail hurried and took two hundred loaves of bread and two skins of wine and five sheep ready dressed and five measures of parched grain and one hundred clusters of raisins and two hundred cakes of figs, and she put them on her donkeys.

19.text: And she said to her young men, Go on before me; I am coming right behind you. But she did not tell her husband Nabal.

20.text: And as she rode on her donkey and came down under the cover of the mountain, David and his men at that moment came down toward her; and she met them.

21.text: Now David had said, It was certainly in vain that I guarded all that this fellow has in the wilderness, so that nothing was missed of all that he has; for he has repaid me evil for good.

22.text: May God do so to David's enemies, and even more, if I leave so much as one male of all that he has until morning.

23.text: And when Abigail saw David, she hurried and got down from her donkey and fell on her face before David; and she bowed herself to the ground.

24.text: And she fell at his feet and said, Upon me alone, my lord, be this iniquity; and let your female servant speak in your hearing, and hear the words of your female servant.

25.text: May my lord not take this worthless man Nabal to heart. For as his name is, so he is: Nabal is his name, and folly is with him. But I your female servant did not see my lord's young men, whom you sent.

26.text: And now, my lord, as Jehovah lives and as your soul lives, since Jehovah has withheld you from entering into bloodshed and from avenging yourself by your own hand, now therefore let your enemies and those who seek harm against my lord be like Nabal.

27.text: And now this present which your servant has brought to my lord, let it be given to the young men who follow my lord.

28.text: Please forgive the transgression of your female servant, for Jehovah will no doubt make a sure house for my lord, because my lord fights the battles of Jehovah; and no evil will be found in you throughout your days.

29.text: And though men rise up to pursue you and to seek your life, my lord's life will be bound up in the bundle of the living with Jehovah your God; and the lives of your enemies He will sling out, as from the hollow of the sling.

30.text: And when Jehovah has done to my lord according to all the good He has spoken concerning you and has appointed you ruler over Israel,

31.text: This will not be a qualm of conscience to you or a stumbling block in heart to my lord, that you shed blood without cause or that my lord has avenged himself. And when Jehovah has dealt well with my lord, may you remember your female servant.

32.text: And David said to Abigail, Blessed be Jehovah, the God of Israel, who sent you this day to meet me.

33.text: And blessed be your discretion; and blessed be you, who have kept me this day from entering into bloodshed and from avenging myself by my own hand.

34.text: For surely as Jehovah the God of Israel lives, who has withheld me from harming you, unless you had hurried and come to meet me, indeed there would not have been left to Nabal even one male until morning's light.

35.text: So David took from her hand what she brought to him. And he said to her, Go up in peace to your house. See, I have listened to your voice and have accepted your person.

36.text: And Abigail went to Nabal. And just then he was having a feast in his house, like the feast of a king. And Nabal's heart was merry within him, and he was extremely drunk; therefore she told him nothing, small or great, until the light of morning.

37.text: And in the morning, when the wine had left Nabal, his wife told him these things. And his heart died within him, and he became like a stone.

38.text: And about ten days later Jehovah struck Nabal, and he died.

39.text: And when David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, Blessed be Jehovah, who has pleaded the cause of my reproach at the hand of Nabal and who has withheld His servant from evildoing; and Jehovah has returned the evildoing of Nabal upon his own head. And David sent men to propose to Abigail, that he might take her to himself as wife.

40.text: And when David's servants came to Abigail at Carmel, they spoke to her, saying, David has sent us to you, to take you to himself as wife.

41.text: And she rose up and fell on her face to the ground. And she said, Here is your female servant, as a slave to wash the feet of my lord's servants.

42.text: And Abigail hurried and rose up; and she rode on a donkey, with her five young women following her. And she went after the messengers of David, and she became his wife.

43.text: David also took Ahinoam of Jezreel; and both of them became his wives.

44.text: Now Saul had given Michal his daughter, David's wife, to Palti the son of Laish, who was from Gallim.

1.text: And the Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah, saying, David is hiding himself on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite the desert!

2.text: And Saul rose up and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, with him three thousand choice men of Israel, to seek David in the wilderness of Ziph.

3.text: And Saul encamped on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite the desert, by the road. And David remained in the wilderness, but he saw that Saul had come into the wilderness after him.

4.text: And David sent spies and knew for certain that Saul had come.

5.text: So David rose up and went to the place where Saul encamped. And David looked on the place where Saul and Abner the son of Ner, the captain of his army, lay. Now Saul was lying within the entrenchment, and the people were encamped around him.

6.text: And David responded and spoke to Ahimelech the Hittite and Abishai the son of Zeruiah, the brother of Joab, saying, Who will go down with me to Saul at the camp? And Abishai said, I will go down with you.

7.text: So David and Abishai went to the people by night; and there lay Saul, sleeping within the entrenchment, and his spear was stuck in the ground by his head. And Abner and the people lay around him.

8.text: And Abishai said to David, God has delivered your enemy into your hand today. Now therefore let me strike him with the spear even to the ground with one stroke, and I will not do it twice.

9.text: But David said to Abishai, Do not destroy him; for who can stretch out his hand against Jehovah's anointed and be guiltless?

10.text: And David said, As Jehovah lives, Jehovah will strike him down, or his day will come to die, or he will go down in battle and perish.

11.text: Jehovah forbid that I should stretch out my hand against Jehovah's anointed. Now therefore take the spear that is by his head and the water jug, and let us go.

12.text: So David took the spear and the water jug by Saul's head, and they went away. And no one saw it or knew about it, nor did anyone awake, for all of them were sleeping; for a deep sleep from Jehovah had fallen upon them.

13.text: And David crossed over to the other side and stood on the top of the hill far off; a great distance was between them.

14.text: And David called out to the people and to Abner the son of Ner, saying, Will you not answer, Abner? And Abner answered and said, Who are you that calls out to the king?

15.text: And David said to Abner, Are you not a man? Who is like you in Israel? Why then have you not guarded your lord the king? For one of the people came in to destroy the king your lord.

16.text: This thing is not good that you have done. As Jehovah lives, you are as good as dead because you did not guard your lord, Jehovah's anointed. Now therefore, see where the king's spear and the water jug that were by his head are.

17.text: And Saul recognized David's voice; and he said, Is this your voice, my son David? And David said, It is my voice, my lord, O king.

18.text: And he said, Why does my lord pursue after his servant? For what have I done? Or what evil is in my hand?

19.text: Now therefore let my lord the king hear the words of his servant. If it is Jehovah who has stirred you up against me, let Him accept an offering; but if it is the sons of men, let them be cursed before Jehovah; for they have driven me out today, so that I cannot share in Jehovah's inheritance, saying, Go, serve other gods.

20.text: Now therefore do not let my blood fall to the ground apart from the presence of Jehovah; for the king of Israel has come forth to seek a single flea, as one might hunt a partridge in the mountains.

21.text: And Saul said, I have sinned. Return, my son David; for I will not harm you anymore, because my life was precious in your sight this day. I have indeed acted foolishly and have made a very great mistake.

22.text: And David answered and said, Here is the spear, O king. Let one of the young men cross over and get it.

23.text: And Jehovah will repay to each man his righteousness and faithfulness: Because Jehovah has delivered you into my hand today, and I would not stretch out my hand against Jehovah's anointed;

24.text: Then just as great as your life was in my eyes this day, so great may my life be in Jehovah's eyes that He would deliver me from all distress.

25.text: And Saul said to David, Blessed are you, my son David. You shall most certainly both do and prevail. And David went on his way, and Saul returned to his place.

1.text: And David said in his heart, I will now one day perish at the hand of Saul. There is nothing better for me than to escape into the land of the Philistines; then Saul will despair of seeking me any longer within all the territory of Israel. Thus I will escape from his hand.

2.text: So David rose up and crossed over, he and the six hundred men who were with him, to Achish the son of Maoch, the king of Gath.

3.text: And David remained with Achish in Gath, he and his men, each man with his household: David and his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelite and Abigail the wife of Nabal, the Carmelite.

4.text: And it was told Saul that David had fled to Gath, so he no longer sought him.

5.text: And David said to Achish, If now I have found favor in your sight, let me be given a place in one of the country towns; and I will dwell there. For why should your servant dwell in the royal city with you?

6.text: So Achish gave him Ziklag that day; therefore Ziklag belongs to the kings of Judah to this day.

7.text: And the length of time that David remained in the country of the Philistines was a year and four months.

8.text: Now David and his men went up and attacked the Geshurites and the Girzites and the Amalekites, for they were the inhabitants of the land from of old, as you go to Shur and unto the land of Egypt.

9.text: And David struck the land; and he left neither man nor woman alive but took the sheep and the oxen and the asses and the camels and the clothing. Then he returned and came to Achish.

10.text: Then Achish said, Against whom have you conducted an attack today? And David said, Against the south of Judah and against the south of the Jerahmeelites and against the south of the Kenites.

11.text: Now David left neither man nor woman alive to be brought to Gath, for he said, Perhaps they will tell of us, saying, Thus did David do. And such was his custom as long as he dwelt in the country of the Philistines.

12.text: And Achish trusted David, saying, He has made himself utterly odious to his people Israel; therefore he shall be my servant forever.

1.text: Then in those days the Philistines gathered their camps together for war to fight against Israel. And Achish said to David, Know assuredly that you shall go out with me into the camp, you and your men.

2.text: And David said to Achish, This being so, you will know what your servant can do. And Achish said to David, Therefore I will make you my bodyguard for life.

3.text: Now Samuel was dead, and all Israel had mourned for him; and they had buried him in Ramah, that is, in his own city. And Saul had the mediums and the soothsayers put out of the land.

4.text: And the Philistines gathered together, and they came and encamped in Shunem; and Saul gathered all Israel together, and they encamped in Gilboa.

5.text: And when Saul saw the camp of the Philistines, he was afraid, and his heart trembled greatly.

6.text: And Saul inquired of Jehovah; but Jehovah did not answer him, not by dreams or by the Urim or by the prophets.

7.text: Then said Saul to his servants, Seek for me a woman who is a medium that I may go to her and inquire of her. And his servants said to him, There is now a woman who is a medium at En-dor.

8.text: Then Saul disguised himself and put on other clothes. And he and two men with him went, and they came to the woman by night. And he said, Consult a departed spirit for me, and bring up to me the one whom I tell you.

9.text: But the woman said to him, Look, you know what Saul has done, that he has cut off the mediums and the soothsayers from the land. Why then do you lay a snare for my life to make me die?

10.text: Then Saul swore to her by Jehovah, saying, As Jehovah lives, no punishment shall happen to you for this thing.

11.text: So the woman said, Whom shall I bring up to you? And he said, Bring up Samuel to me.

12.text: Now when the woman saw Samuel, she cried out with a loud voice; and the woman spoke to Saul, saying, Why have you deceived me? For you are Saul.

13.text: And the king said to her, Do not be afraid. But what do you see? And the woman said to Saul, I see some divine being coming up out of the earth.

14.text: And he said to her, What is his appearance? And she said, An old man is coming up; and he is wrapped in a cloak. Then Saul knew that it was Samuel, and he bowed with his face to the ground and paid him homage.

15.text: And Samuel said to Saul, Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up? And Saul said, I am greatly distressed; for the Philistines wage war against me, and God has turned away from me and answers me no more, neither through the prophets nor by dreams. Therefore I have called you, that you may make known to me what I shall do.

16.text: And Samuel said, Why then have you inquired of me? For Jehovah has turned away from you and become your adversary.

17.text: And Jehovah has done for Himself just as He spoke through me, for Jehovah has torn the kingdom out from your hand and given it to an associate of yours, to David.

18.text: Because you did not listen to the voice of Jehovah and did not execute His burning anger upon the Amalekites, therefore Jehovah has done this thing to you this day.

19.text: And Jehovah will also give Israel with you into the hand of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons will be with me; Jehovah will also give the camp of Israel into the hand of the Philistines.

20.text: Then immediately Saul fell his full length to the ground, and he was very afraid because of Samuel's words. And there was no strength in him, for he had not eaten food all day and all night.

21.text: And the woman came to Saul and saw that he was very troubled. And she said to him, Indeed, your servant has listened to your voice; and I have put my life in my hand and have listened to your words which you spoke to me.

22.text: Now therefore, you listen also to the voice of your servant, and let me set a morsel of bread before you; and eat, that you may have strength when you go on your way.

23.text: But he refused and said, I will not eat. Then his servants, as well as the woman, compelled him, and he listened to their voice; and he rose up from the ground and sat on the bed.

24.text: And the woman had a fattened calf in the house; and she hurried and killed it, and took flour and kneaded it, and baked unleavened bread with it.

25.text: And she brought it before Saul and his servants, and they ate. And they rose up and went away that night.

1.text: And the Philistines gathered all their camps together at Aphek; and Israel encamped by the spring that is in Jezreel.

2.text: And the lords of the Philistines passed on by hundreds and by thousands; and David and his men passed on at the rear with Achish.

3.text: And the princes of the Philistines said, What are these Hebrews doing here? And Achish said to the princes of the Philistines, Is this not David, the servant of Saul the king of Israel, who has been with me these days, or even these years? And I have found nothing wrong in him since the day he deserted to me to this day.

4.text: But the princes of the Philistines were angry with him. And the princes of the Philistines said to him, Make the man go back, that he may return to his place that you have assigned him, so that he does not go down with us into the battle and does not become our adversary in the battle. For with what might this man reconcile himself to his master? Will it not be with the heads of these men?

5.text: Is this not David, of whom they sang to one another in dances, saying, Saul has struck down his thousands; / But David, his ten thousands?

6.text: And Achish called David and said to him, As Jehovah lives, you are upright, and it is acceptable in my sight that you go forth and come in with me in the camp; for I have not found evil in you since the day you came to me to this day. But you are not acceptable to the lords.

7.text: Now therefore return and go in peace, so that you do not do anything displeasing to the lords of the Philistines.

8.text: And David said to Achish, But what have I done? And what wrong have you found in your servant since the day I began to be with you to this day, that I should not go and fight against the enemies of my lord the king?

9.text: And Achish answered and said to David, I know that you are as acceptable to me as an angel of God; nevertheless the princes of the Philistines have said, He shall not go up with us into the battle.

10.text: Now therefore rise up early in the morning with your master's servants who came with you; indeed rise up early in the morning, and when you have daylight, go.

11.text: So David rose up early, he and his men, to go in the morning, to return into the land of the Philistines. And the Philistines went up to Jezreel.

1.text: And when David and his men came to Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had made a raid upon the south and upon Ziklag; and they had struck Ziklag and burned it with fire.

2.text: And they had taken the women and all who were in it captive, both small and great; they had killed none, but had carried them off, and had gone on their way.

3.text: And David and his men came to the city; and there it was, burned with fire. And their wives and their sons and their daughters had been taken captive.

4.text: And David and the people who were with him lifted up their voice and wept until they had no strength to weep.

5.text: And David's two wives had been taken captive, Ahinoam the Jezreelite and Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.

6.text: And David was very distressed because the people spoke of stoning him, for the soul of all the people was bitter, every man because of his sons and his daughters. But David strengthened himself in Jehovah his God.

7.text: And David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelech, Bring the ephod to me. So Abiathar brought the ephod to David.

8.text: And David inquired of Jehovah, saying, Shall I pursue after this band? Will I overtake them? And He said to him, Pursue, for you will certainly overtake them, and you will certainly deliver them.

9.text: So David went, he and the six hundred men who were with him; and they came to the brook Besor, where those who were left stayed behind.

10.text: And David pursued, he and four hundred men; for two hundred stayed behind, who were too exhausted to cross over the brook Besor.

11.text: And they found an Egyptian in the field and brought him to David. And they gave him food, and he ate; and they gave him water to drink.

12.text: And they gave him a piece of fig cake and two raisin cakes; and he ate, and his spirit returned to him; for he had eaten no food and had drunk no water for three days and three nights.

13.text: And David said to him, To whom do you belong and where are you from? And he said, I am a young man of Egypt, the servant of an Amalekite man; and my master abandoned me because I fell sick three days ago.

14.text: We attacked the south of the Cherethites and what belongs to Judah and the south of Caleb; and we burned Ziklag with fire.

15.text: And David said to him, Can you lead me down to this band? And he said, Swear to me by God that you will neither kill me nor deliver me into the hand of my master, and I will lead you down to this troop.

16.text: And he led him down; and there they were, spread over the whole land, eating and drinking and celebrating because of all the great spoil that they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.

17.text: And David struck them from twilight until the evening of the next day; and not a man of them escaped except for four hundred young men, who rode upon camels and fled.

18.text: And David delivered all that the Amalekites had taken; and David delivered his two wives.

19.text: And nothing was missed by them, neither small nor great, neither sons nor daughters, neither spoil nor anything that they had taken; David brought everything back.

20.text: And David took all the flocks and the herds, which they drove before the other cattle and of which they said, This is David's spoil.

21.text: Then David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow David and who had been left behind at the brook Besor. And they went forth to meet David and to meet the people who were with him; and David came near to the people and greeted them.

22.text: And all the wicked and worthless men among the men that had gone with David responded; and they said, Because they did not go with us, we will not give them anything of the spoil that we have delivered, except every man his wife and his children that they may lead them off and go away.

23.text: Then said David, You shall not do so, my brothers, with that which Jehovah has given us, who has kept us and given this band that came against us into our hand.

24.text: And who will listen to you in this matter? For as his share is who goes down to the battle, so shall his share be who stays by the baggage; they shall share alike.

25.text: And from that day forward he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel unto this day.

26.text: And David came to Ziklag, and he sent some of the spoil to the elders of Judah, to his companions, saying, Here is a present for you from the spoil of the enemies of Jehovah:

27.text: For those in Bethel, and for those in Ramoth of the south, and for those in Jattir,

28.text: And for those in Aroer, and for those in Siphmoth, and for those in Eshtemoa,

29.text: And for those in Racal, and for those in the cities of the Jerahmeelites, and for those in the cities of the Kenites,

30.text: And for those in Hormah, and for those in Bor-ashan, and for those in Athach,

31.text: And for those in Hebron, and for all the places where David himself and his men had gone about.

1.text: Now the Philistines were fighting against Israel; and the men of Israel fled from before the Philistines and fell down slain on Mount Gilboa.

2.text: And the Philistines chased Saul and his sons; and the Philistines struck down Jonathan and Abinadab and Malchi-shua, Saul's sons.

3.text: And the battle bore heavily against Saul, and the archers hit him; and he was badly wounded by the archers.

4.text: Then Saul said to his armor bearer, Draw your sword, and thrust me through with it, lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through and abuse me. But his armor bearer would not, for he was very afraid. So Saul took his sword and fell on it.

5.text: And when his armor bearer saw that Saul was dead, he likewise fell on his sword and died with him.

6.text: So Saul and his three sons and his armor bearer, as well as all his men, died that day together.

7.text: And when the men of Israel who were on the other side of the valley and who were on the other side of the Jordan saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they forsook the cities and fled; and the Philistines came and dwelt in them.

8.text: And the next day the Philistines came to strip the slain, and they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.

9.text: And they cut off his head and stripped off his armor; and they sent them all around, throughout the land of the Philistines in order to announce the good news in the houses of their idols and to the people.

10.text: And they put his armor in the house of Ashtaroth; and they fastened his body to the wall of Beth-shan.

11.text: And when the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,

12.text: All the valiant men rose up and went all night and took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan; and they came to Jabesh and burned them there.

13.text: And they took their bones and buried them under the tamarisk at Jabesh, and they fasted seven days.
